persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: AthanasiusKircher
persons.description: Prolific German Jesuit scholar and polymath who published many book, including on geology.

works.name: Mundus subterraneus, quo universae denique naturae divitiae

places.name: The Colosseum
places.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

places.name: Gabii
places.description: Gabii was an ancient city of Latium on the perimeter of an extinct volcanic crater lake.

places.name: Alexandrine Aqueduct
places.description: Also known as the Aquedutto Alexandrina or Aqua Alexandrina. Built in the 3rd century CE to carry water to Rome.

places.name: Palazzo Campanella
places.description: possibly: palazzo Baldassarre Lomellini also known as palazzo di Cristoforo Spinola or palazzo Campanella, a 16th century building in Genoa.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

persons.name: Onuphrio
persons.description: Onuphiro is the name of a fictional character in the dialogues of Davy's Consolations in Travel. The anglicized version of the name is Humphry.

places.name: Edinburgh
places.description: The capital city of Scotland.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnPlayfair
persons.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

places.name: River Thames
places.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

places.name: Paestum
places.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

places.name: Agrigento
places.description: Agrigento is a hilltop city on Sicily's southwest shore. It's known for the ruins of the ancient city of Akragas in the Valley of the Temples, a vast archaeological site with well-preserved Greek temples.

persons.name: Onuphrio

places.name: New Holland
places.description: New Holland was the name first given to Australia by the Dutch seafarer, Abel Tasman.

places.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

places.name: County Antrim

places.name: Giant's Causeway
places.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

places.name: Anatolia
places.description: Also known as Asia Minor. A large peninsula in West Asia it is the western-most extension of continental Asia as it borders European Turkey.

places.name: The Holy Land
places.description: an area roughly located between the Mediterranean Sea and the eastern bank of the Jordan River, traditionally synonymous both with the biblical Land of Israel and with the region of Palestine. Today, the term "Holy Land" usually refers to a territory roughly corresponding to the modern states of Israel and Palestine. Jews, Christians, Muslims, and Baháʼís regard it as holy.

persons.name: ClaudiusPtolemy
persons.description: An Alexandrian mathematician, astronomer, astrologer, geographer, and music theorist. His Almagest supporting a geocentric view of the world was not seriously contradicted until the work of Copernicus.

places.name: Judaea
places.description: The southernmost of the three traditional divisions of ancient Palestine; there are political and religious disputes over what to call this land today.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

places.name: Jerusalem
places.description: Jerusalem is an ancient city in West Asia, on a plateau in the Judaean Mountains between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea.

persons.name: Barnaba Niccolò Maria LuigiChiaramonti
persons.description: Pope Pius VII, 1800-1823, held prisioner by Buonparte, 1809-1813. In February 1814 Davy and his party stayed in the same inn that Pius had used the week before on his way back to Rome.

persons.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
persons.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

places.name: Ogwen Quarry
places.description: Probably Penrhyn Quarry, which produced Ogwen slate in the Ogwen Valley in Wales.

places.name: The Holy Sepulchre
places.description: The Church of the Holy Sepulchre:  fourth-century church in the Christian Quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem. It is considered to be the holiest site for Christians in the world, as it is said to contain the site of Jesus's crucifixion and the tomb in which he was buried prior to his resurrection.

places.name: Black Sea
places.description: The Black Sea is a marginal Mediterranean sea lying between Europe and Asia, east of the Balkans, south of the East European Plain, west of the Caucasus, and north of Anatolia.

places.name: Sava River
places.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

places.name: Bad Aussee
places.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

places.name: Hallstätter See
places.description: Hallstatter is a lake in Austria named after the small town on its shore.

places.name: Tyrol

places.name: Lake Toplitz
places.description: A lake in a dense forest high in the Austrian Alps.

places.name: Ebensee
places.description: Ebensee is a market town in the Traunviertel region of the Austrian state of Upper Austria, located within the Salzkammergut Mountains at the southern end of the Traunsee.

places.name: Traun
places.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

places.name: Adige
places.description: The second-longest river in Italy, which rises in the province of South Tyrol, near the Italian border with Austria and Switzerland.

places.name: Manhart
places.description: Mangart is a mountain in the Julian Alps on the border between Austria and Slovenia.

places.name: Triglav
places.description: Also known as Terglou. Triglav is the highest mountain in Slovenia, located in the Julian Alps.

places.name: Illyrian Alps
places.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

places.name: Wurzen Pass
places.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).

places.name: Lake Cerknica
places.description: An intermittent lake in the southern part of the Cerknica Polje, a region in south-western Slovenia.

places.name: Ljubljana
places.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

places.name: Sava River

places.name: Postojna

places.name: Cerknica
places.description: Known in German as Zirknitz, Cerknica is a town in the Karst region of southwestern Slovenia.

places.name: Lizard Point
places.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

persons.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.
